elements.content: Reaction of the chiral amine (S)-N-α-(methylbenzyl)phenylallylamine, [(S)-N-α-mbpa], with nBuM (M = Li, Na, K) in the presence of the Lewis donors TMEDA or THF (TMEDA = N,N,N′,N′-tetramethylethylenediamine, THF = tetrahydrofuran) resulted in a series of mono- or dimetalated complexes, [{PhC(H)CH3NC(H)C(H)C(H)PhLi2(TMEDA)2] 1, [{PhC(H)CH3NCHCHCH2PhNa(TMEDA)]2 2, and [PhC(CH2)N(CH2CH2CH3)K]∞ 3, being formed with various 1,3-sigmatropic rearranged allylic bonding patterns. Completing previous work on the related amine N-α-(methylbenzyl)allylamine, the potassiated aza-enolate complex [(R)-{(PhC(CH2)N(CH2CH2CH3(THF)]∞ 4 is also reported. All four complexes 1–4 have been characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and solution NMR spectroscopy studies. DTF calculations on model systems investigated the preference for the monomeric Li2-mbpa 1 to undergo isomerization to the aza-allyl anion conformation, which, interestingly, is more energetically stable as a monomeric complex.

All four complexes 1-4 have been characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and solution NMR spectroscopy studies. elements.content: Structural and solution-state investigations of chiral alkali metal amides have experienced a period of steady growth over the last 10 years largely due to their extensive use as chiral auxiliaries and reagents in asymmetric synthesis. In particular, chiral lithium amides play a prominent role in asymmetric deprotonation and addition reactions, allowing for the synthesis of biologically important molecules, such as β-amino acids and β-lactams, with high enantioselectivity. Understanding the stereoselectivity of such reactions, and the structural chemistry of the reactive species or any intermediate complexes formed, allows more efficient and effective reagents to be designed.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Structural and solution-state investigations of chiral alkali metal amides have experienced a period of steady growth over the last 10 years largely due to their extensive use as chiral auxiliaries and reagents in asymmetric synthesis. In particular, chiral lithium amides play a prominent role in asymmetric deprotonation and addition reactions, allowing for the synthesis of biologically important molecules, such as β-amino acids and β-lactams, with high enantioselectivity. Understanding the stereoselectivity of such reactions, and the structural chemistry of the reactive species or any intermediate complexes formed, allows more efficient and effective reagents to be designed.

elements.content: To this end, there have been several systematic investigations into the solid- and solution-state chemistry of both chiral and achiral metal amides. In particular, Williard and Hilmerson have highlighted the diverse nature of chiral lithium amide aggregates and the subtle, yet dramatic, effects the addition of Lewis donors or solvent choice can have in determining the most reactive species.
elements.clean_text: To this end, there have been several systematic investigations into the solid- and solution-state chemistry of both chiral and achiral metal amides. In particular, Williard and Hilmerson have highlighted the diverse nature of chiral lithium amide aggregates and the subtle, yet dramatic, effects the addition of Lewis donors or solvent choice can have in determining the most reactive species.

elements.content: While the solution- and solid-state chemistry of the majority of metal amides produce few surprises, in recent years, we have demonstrated that anion rearrangements and unusual structures can result even when attempting the synthesis of homochiral alkali metal amides from simple commonly used chiral (and achiral) amines. Both dibenzylamine and α-(methylbenzyl)benzylamine on reaction with the right combination of ligand systems and alkali metal will undergo facile hydrogen elimination to form the corresponding 2-aza-allyl complexes. Structural analysis of the products arising from the monometalation of the related homoallylic chiral amine, (S)-N-α-(methylbenzyl)allylamine ((S)-N-mba), revealed the formation of three distinct isomeric anionic forms: allylamide [(PhC(H)CH3NCH2CHCH2)]¯, aza-allyl [(PhC(H)CH3NC(H)CHCH3)]¯, and aza-enolate [(PhC(CH2)N(CH2CH2CH3)]¯ (Figure ). Which anion is formed is highly dependent on the nature of the metal, Lewis donor, and temperature used. In particular, the formation of the 1-aza-allyl and aza-enolate forms of the anion were shown and calculated to be thermodynamically favored when high temperatures, high denticity donors, and Na rather than Li were used.

elements.content: Three isomeric anionic forms formed on metalation of (S)-N-α-(methylbenzyl)allylamine.
elements.clean_text: 1  Three isomeric anionic forms formed on metalation of (S)-N-α-(methylbenzyl)allylamine.

elements.content: One key observation we made at the time was that metalation with lithium in conjunction with a monodentate donor (Et2O, THF, HMPA; THF = tetrahydrofuran, Et2O = diethylether, HMPA = hexamethylphosphoric triamide) did not result in the allyl to 1-aza-allyl conversion unless the sample was heated for a prolonged period. This explains why Davies only ever observed the expected β-amino products when the lithium amide was used in conjugate addition reactions with α,β-unsaturated esters. This contrasts strongly with application of the sodium complex, which, as described, converts easily to the 1-aza-allyl complex and gives instead an enantiomerically pure aminocyclohexane with six new vicinal stereogenic centers.

This explains why Davies only ever observed the expected β-amino products when the lithium amide was used in conjugate addition reactions with α,β-unsaturated esters. This contrasts strongly with application of the sodium complex, which, as described, converts easily to the 1-aza-allyl complex and gives instead an enantiomerically pure aminocyclohexane with six new vicinal stereogenic centers.

elements.content: Yus and co-workers had earlier described the formation of the dilithiated complex through treatment of the lithium allylamide by tBuLi. A subsequent series of reactions with a variety of electrophiles provided evidence that the metals were bonded to the amido-N and vinylic carbon anionic centers with retention of the allylic conformation. Later, we confirmed that this is, indeed, the case through an analysis of the solid- and solution-state chemistry of the dilithiated complex and showed that this is true even when the second metalation is conducted with nBuNa or nBuK in place of tBuLi, resulting in heterobimetallic (Li/Na, Li/K), heterodianionic (N–/C–) complexes. The key structural difference being the gradual move away from σ to π bonding as the second metal is changed from Li to Na and then K. Attempts at forming analogous heterobimetallic complexes from the sodium allylamide failed, primarily because the allylamide rearranges to an 1-aza-allyl complex, making the second metalation unfavorable.

elements.content: Keen on extending our investigations into the subtle electronic and structural effects at play in this system, we decided to synthesize a related chiral amine with an additional phenyl group at the vinylic carbon, (S)-N-α-(methylbenzyl)-3-phenylprop-2-enamine [(S)-N-α-mbpa]. This provides an opportunity to assess the significance of this second electron-rich internal π donor on the structural chemistry of the mono- and dimetalated complexes, with a particular interest in the possible impact of extended anion conjugation on anion formation and stability.
elements.clean_text: Keen on extending our investigations into the subtle electronic and structural effects at play in this system, we decided to synthesize a related chiral amine with an additional phenyl group at the vinylic carbon, (S)-N-α-(methylbenzyl)-3-phenylprop-2-enamine [(S)-N-α-mbpa]. This provides an opportunity to assess the significance of this second electron-rich internal π donor on the structural chemistry of the mono- and dimetalated complexes, with a particular interest in the possible impact of extended anion conjugation on anion formation and stability.

elements.content: Herein, we now report the formation and structural analysis of four new unusual complexes featuring different anionic scaffolds, namely, [{PhC(H)CH3NC(H)C(H)C(H)PhLi2(TMEDA)2] 1, [{PhC(H)CH3NCHCHCH2PhNa(TMEDA)]2 2, and [PhC(CH2)N(CH2CH2CH3)K]∞ 3 (TMEDA = N,N,N′,N′-tetramethylethylenediamine), from (S)-N-α-mbpa, and the potassium aza-enolate anion [(R)-{(PhC(CH2)N(CH2CH2CH3(THF)]∞ 4 from (R)-N-mba. All four complexes have been fully analyzed via single-crystal X-ray diffraction and solution NMR spectroscopic studies.

elements.content: The three complexes of (S)-N-mbpa were prepared as shown in Scheme . Compound 1 was synthesized by addition of 1 equivalent of nBuLi to a hexane solution of (S)-N-mbpa at −50 °C. After warming to room temperature, the oily red solution was allowed to stir for 1 h before addition of TMEDA and sonication for 30 min. Storage of the dark red solution at room temperature for 24 h furnished a crop of red rhombic crystals of complex 1 in a 42% yield. Multiple attempts at the rational synthesis of 1, using 2 equiv of nBuLi and TMEDA or nBuLi/tBuLi mixtures with TMEDA, resulted in the formation of red oils and solids that produced no crystalline products. Analysis of the oils by NMR spectroscopy revealed a complicated mixture of species. Extending this chemistry to sodium, 2 was synthesized by the reaction of nBuNa with (S)-N-mbpa in hexane at 0 °C. Addition of TMEDA and reduction of the solvent volume in vacuo furnished a large crop of light yellow prism crystals of complex 2 in a 81% yield. Completing the series, the potassium analogue 3 was synthesized via the reaction of nBuK with (S)-N-mbpa in a hexane/THF solution at 0 °C. Storage of the solution at room temperature deposited a large crop of yellow needle crystals of complex 3 in a 76% yield.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The three complexes of (S)-N-mbpa were prepared as shown in Scheme . Compound 1 was synthesized by addition of 1 equivalent of nBuLi to a hexane solution of (S)-N-mbpa at -50 °C. After warming to room temperature, the oily red solution was allowed to stir for 1 h before addition of TMEDA and sonication for 30 min. Storage of the dark red solution at room temperature for 24 h furnished a crop of red rhombic crystals of complex 1 in a 42% yield. Multiple attempts at the rational synthesis of 1, using 2 equiv of nBuLi and TMEDA or nBuLi/tBuLi mixtures with TMEDA, resulted in the formation of red oils and solids that produced no crystalline products. Analysis of the oils by NMR spectroscopy revealed a complicated mixture of species. Extending this chemistry to sodium, 2 was synthesized by the reaction of nBuNa with (S)-N-mbpa in hexane at 0 °C. Addition of TMEDA and reduction of the solvent volume in vacuo furnished a large crop of light yellow prism crystals of complex 2 in a 81% yield. Completing the series, the potassium analogue 3 was synthesized via the reaction of nBuK with (S)-N-mbpa in a hexane/THF solution at 0 °C. Storage of the solution at room temperature deposited a large crop of yellow needle crystals of complex 3 in a 76% yield.

elements.content: Turning to (S)-N-mba, its reaction with nBuK in a hexane/THF solution at 0 °C resulted in a crop of yellow plate crystals that were unfortunately unsuitable for X-ray analysis. Changing to the enantiomer (R)-N-mba, its reaction with nBuK in a hexane/THF solution at 0 °C resulted in a crop of yellow crystals of 4 in 85% yield. The isolated crystals from all four reactions were investigated by single-crystal X-ray analysis and solution NMR studies.

elements.content: A summary of the crystallographic data for all four complexes 1–4 is provided in the . X-ray crystallographic studies on 1 revealed the presence of the unexpected dilithiated product despite the fact that only 1 equiv of nBuLi was used in the synthesis, suggesting 1 to be the more thermodynamically stable product of the reaction. Looking at the molecular structure of 1 (Figure ), the allylamine has been deprotonated at the N(1) and C(11) atom sites with the phenylallylamine undergoing an internal 1,3-sigmatropic rearrangement characterized by the bond lengths of 1.396(2), 1.379(2), and 1.448(2) Å for N(1)–C(9), C(9)–C(10), and C(10)–C(11), respectively. The central 1-aza-allyl moiety in 1 is sandwiched between two Li cations that are slightly unsymmetrical in their bonding due to the orientation of the chelating bidentate TMEDA donors. Examining the orientation of C(7)–N(1)–C(9)–C(10), it is evident that the aza-allyl moiety is strictly planar with respect to the perpendicular Li(1)–Li(2) axis [89.67(3)°] with both phenyl groups lying out of this plane by 13.75(5)° [phenyl C(1)–C(6)] and 34.502(6)° [phenyl C(12)–C(17)].
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Structures

A summary of the crystallographic data for all four complexes 1-4 is provided in the . X-ray crystallographic studies on 1 revealed the presence of the unexpected dilithiated product despite the fact that only 1 equiv of nBuLi was used in the synthesis, suggesting 1 to be the more thermodynamically stable product of the reaction. Looking at the molecular structure of 1 (Figure ), the allylamine has been deprotonated at the N(1) and C(11) atom sites with the phenylallylamine undergoing an internal 1,3-sigmatropic rearrangement characterized by the bond lengths of 1.396(2), 1.379(2), and 1.448(2) Å for N(1)-C(9), C(9)-C(10), and C(10)-C(11), respectively. The central 1-aza-allyl moiety in 1 is sandwiched between two Li cations that are slightly unsymmetrical in their bonding due to the orientation of the chelating bidentate TMEDA donors. Examining the orientation of C(7)-N(1)-C(9)-C(10), it is evident that the aza-allyl moiety is strictly planar with respect to the perpendicular Li(1)-Li(2) axis [89.67(3)°] with both phenyl groups lying out of this plane by 13.75(5)° [phenyl C(1)-C(6)] and 34.502(6)° [phenyl C(12)-C(17)].

elements.content: Molecular structure of [{PhC(H)CH3NC(H)C(H)C(H)Ph}Li2(TMEDA)2] 1 showing thermal ellipsoids at 50% probability. Hydrogen atoms (except aza-allyl ones) have been omitted for clarity. Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg): Li(1)–N(1), 2.019(4); Li(1)–N(2), 2.111(4); Li(1)–N(3), 2.151(4); Li(1)–C(9), 2.227(4); Li(1)–C(10), 2.420(4); Li(1)–C(11), 2.559(4); Li(2)–N(1), 2.056(4); Li(2)–N(4), 2.146(4); Li(2)–N(5), 2.136(4); Li(2)–C(9), 2.280(4); Li(2)–C(10), 2.405(4); Li(2)–C(11), 2.358(4); C(7)–N(1), 1.456(2); N(1)–C(9), 1.96(2); C(9)–C(10), 1.379(2); C(10–C(11), 1.448(2); C(7)–C(8), 1.538(3); Li(1)–N(1)–Li(2), 109.72(16); N(2)–Li(1)–N(3), 86.01(15); N(5)–Li(2)–N(4), 86.49(14); C(10)–C(9)–N(1), 121.14(16); Li(1)–C(9)–Li(2), 95.34(14); C(9)–C(10)–C(11), 124.93(16); Li(2)–C(10)–Li(1), 87.36(13); Li(2)–C(11)–Li(1), 85.23(13).

Each Li cation in 1 is in a highly coordinated environment forming close electrostatic contacts with all the carbon atoms of the aza-allyl group, the amido N atom [Li(1)–N(1) 2.019(4) Å and Li(2)–N(1) 2.056(4) Å], and the N atoms of the donor TMEDA molecule. The Li–C bond lengths in 1 range from 2.227(4) to 2.559(4) Å for Li(1)–C(9) to Li(1)–C(11) with both Li(1) and Li(2) forming close contacts with all the carbons in the aza-allyl moiety of the ligand. Previously, within our group, we have reported the dilithiation of the allyl amide derivative (S)-N-mba, which exists as a cyclic hexamer in the absence of a donor [(PhC(H)CH3NCH2CHCHLi2)]6 5 and as a dimer in the presence of TMEDA [(PhC(H)CH3NCH2CHCH)Li2(TMEDA)]2 6. However, unlike complexes 5 and 6, which retain their original allyl-amide system after deprotonation, complex 1 undergoes an internal 1,3-sigmatropic rearrangement, forming the new η1-N-aza-allyl dianion, which exists as a monomer in the solid state. Table compares key bond lengths in 1 with those of 5 and 6, showing that they are in good agreement with each other.

The Li-C bond lengths in 1 range from 2.227(4) to 2.559(4) Å for Li(1)-C(9) to Li(1)-C(11) with both Li(1) and Li(2) forming close contacts with all the carbons in the aza-allyl moiety of the ligand. Moving to sodium, the crystal structure of 2 shown in Figure is a noncentrosymmetric dimer in which each of the two “monomers” adopt a different conformation. Analysis of the bond lengths in the N(1)–C(9)–C(10)–C(11) [1.353(5), 1.387(6), 1.513(5) Å] and N(4)–C(32)–C(33)–C(34) [1.369(5), 1.372(6), 1.498(6) Å] fragments of the ligand indicates that the double bond has moved, most likely through a facile 1,3-sigmatropic rearrangement, allowing 2 to be best described as an η1-N-aza-allyl complex, originally seen in complex 1.

Complex 2 is essentially isostructural to the sodium (S)-N-mba analogue [{PhC(H)­CH3­NCHCH­CH3}2­Na2(TMEDA)2] (7). Listed in Table are the key structural dimensions of 2 alongside those of 7. The main feature of compound 2 is the central four-membered (NaN)2 ring, about which the amido functionalities are in a trans arrangement. The four-membered ring is not strictly planar but adopts a shallow butterfly conformation, deviating from the plane by 8.6°. The sodium atoms adopt tetrahedral geometries, each coordinated to a bidentate chelating TMEDA molecule (one of which is disordered over two positions) and two amide N atoms of the (S)-N-mbpa ligand. Although the formal coordination number of the sodium atoms is four, both are able to form short electrostatic interactions with the nearby C and H atoms of the aza-allyl groups. The shortest contacts are Na(1) to C(9) and C(10) at 2.910(4) and 3.078(4) Å, respectively, while comparable distances for Na(2) are 2.885(4) and 3.099(4) Å for C(32) and C(33), respectively. The nitrogen atoms of the (S)-N-mbpa ligand adopt a distorted tetrahedral geometry (average bond angle = 108.18°), most likely due to steric reasons, with the aza-allyl groups forming acute angles in relation to the (NaN)2 ring. As a result, N(1)–N(4)–C(32) and N(4)–N(1)–C(9) are 108.95° and 99.42°, respectively, while the concomitant angles to the benzylic carbon are 144.89° for N(4)–N(1)–C(7) and 132.71° for N(1)–N(4)–C(30). Within the ring, the Na–N(amide) bond lengths are significantly longer than those found in 7 [2.410(2)–2.389(2) Å], [(TMEDA)Na{N(Me)(CH2Ph)}]2 [2.391(2)–2.351(3) Å], and [(TMEDA)Na(TMP)]2 [2.249–2.402 Å] but are similar to those observed for the dimers [(iPr)2NNa(TMEDA)]2 [2.441(2)–2.453(3) Å] and [(TMEDA)Na(NPh2)]2 [2.422(2)–2.484(2) Å], which could be due to the steric nature of the groups attached to the amide moiety.

Previous attempts within our group to crystallize potassium complexes of (S/R)-N-mba have proved unsuccessful, resulting in the isolation of highly viscous impure oils. However, here, using low temperatures and a hexane/THF reaction mixture, we report the first monopotassiated complexes of (S)-N-mbpa (3) and (R)-N-mba (4).

elements.content: Figure highlights the defining mononuclear section of 3, whereas Figure shows a longer section of its polymeric structure. Polynuclear 3 has rearranged to an η1-N-aza-enolate, containing a newly formed delocalized double bond [ C(7)–C(8), 1.372(5) Å] in the former benzylmethyl moiety with loss of chirality at C(7) and saturation [C(9)–C(10), 1.556(6) Å; C(10)–C(11), 1.501(6) Å; C(11)–C(12), 1.505(6) Å] of the former aza-allyl group. To appreciate the complete coordination environment around the K cation, it is necessary to look at complex 3 in its polymeric aggregation state (Figure ). The formation of the polymeric chain involves the association of (KN)2 rings with the two aza-enolate moieties adopting a pseudo trans configuration with respect to the ring. Each potassium cation coordinates to three nitrogen atoms, the lengths of which fall into two categories: short [K(1)–N(1)′, 2.719(3) Å] and long [K(1)–N(1), 3.214(3) Å; K(1)–N(1)″, 3.166(3) Å], which are both within the range of typical potassium amide (ca. 2.7–2.8 Å) and dative bonds. Each potassium also engages in electrostatic interactions with the aza-enolate unit [K(1)–C(7), 2.971(3) Å; K(1)–C(8), 3.062(3) Å] and to the nearby hydrogen atom H(9B) [K(1)–H(9B), 2.980(5) Å] (Figure ).

elements.content: Interestingly, despite an excess of THF being added to the reaction mixture, there is no coordination of any solvent (THF) molecules in the molecular structure of 3. This would suggest that electrostatic interactions between the potassium center and the aza-enolate functionality are sufficiently strong enough to exclude THF from its coordination sphere, allowing 3 to retain its polymeric framework. Our group studied these facile anion rearrangements in the similar amide (S)-N-mba, investigating the influence of the alkali metal and donor denticity on the choice of anion formed. DFT calculations revealed that both the aza-ally and the aza-enolate anions are of comparable stability, but as the denticity of the donor increases, the aza-enolate anion becomes more favorable and stable. These findings were also confirmed structurally by the isolation of the Li and Na complexes of all three anion rearrangements with varying denticity donors (THF, TMEDA, and PMDETA). Interestingly, despite no donor molecules being present in the molecular structure of 3, the aza-enolate form of the anion is observed. It is well documented that potassium cations will preferentially bond with delocalized systems to the exclusion of donor solvents, making the coordination environment of potassium in 3 not unique. A pertinent example of such a π-cation interaction versus donor solvent inclusion is the mixed potassium calcium complex [(Ph(Me)N)4K2Ca]∞, in which, despite being synthesized in THF, the donor solvent is excluded from the structure with potassium preferentially π-interacting with three phenyl groups.

elements.content: Moving to the amide ligand α-(methylbenzyl)allylamine, repeated attempts to obtain suitable crystals of the potassium (S)-enantiomer complex proved unsuccessful. Changing to the (R)-enantiomer, (R)-N-mba was reacted with nBuK in a hexane/THF solution, which deposited a crop of single crystals of 4, which, by X-ray analysis, revealed the complex to be polymeric in the solid state [(R)-{(PhC(CH2)N(CH2CH2CH3)K}2(THF)]∞ (Figure ).

elements.content: Similar to 3, complex 4 has rearranged to an η1-N-aza-enolate. Figure selects the defining mononuclear section of 4, whereas Figure shows a longer section of its polymeric structure. The asymmetric unit has one K cation with K(2) effectively sandwiched between two aza-enolate anions. The rearranged anion is characterized by the C(7)–C(8), C(7)–N(1), C(18)–C(19), and C(18)–N(2) bond distances in each ligand, which are 1.377(5), 1.344(4), 1.369(5), and 1.331(5) Å, respectively. The K–N bond distances lie in the longer range of 2.830(3) and 3.038(3) Å for K(1)–N(1) and K(2)–N(2), respectively, in comparison to other potassium–amide complexes [(Me3Si)2NK] (2.770(3), 2.803(3) Å), [(Me2 tBuSi)(Me2Si)NK]2 (2.764(1), 2.784(1) Å), and [(TMEDA)K(TMP)]2 (range of 2.744(2)–2.836(2) Å). Examining the orientation of C(9)–N(1)–C(7)–C(8) and C(19)–N(2)–C(17)–C(18), the aza-enolate moiety with respect to the propyl group is strictly planar, reflecting the inclusion of the N atom in delocalization.

elements.content: The coordination sphere of K(1) is composed of one aza-enolate moiety bonded via the N atom [K(1)–N(1), 2.830(3) Å], a coordinated THF [K(1)–O(1), 2.768(3) Å], and several K–C atom π-interactions [K(1)–C(9), 3.375(4) Å; K(1)–C(10), 3.314(4) Å]. K(2), which is in a higher coordination environment, forms close interactions with both aza-enolate ligands via K–N bonds, one short [K(2)–N(2), 2.870(3) Å] and one long [K(2)–N(1), 3.038(3) Å], as well as forming numerous π-electrostatic K–C bond interactions with both aza-enolate moieties [range of 2.921(3)–3.375(4) Å]. These close K–C contacts result in no THF being coordinated to K(2), even though an excess of the Lewis donor was used in the synthesis.

K(2), which is in a higher coordination environment, forms close interactions with both aza-enolate ligands via K-N bonds, one short [K(2)-N(2), 2.870(3) Å] and one long [K(2)-N(1), 3.038(3) Å], as well as forming numerous π-electrostatic K-C bond interactions with both aza-enolate moieties [range of 2.921(3)-3.375(4) Å]. These close K-C contacts result in no THF being coordinated to K(2), even though an excess of the Lewis donor was used in the synthesis.

elements.content: Comparable to 3, polymeric aggregation is favored in 4, with the presence of excess THF, which is unable to deaggregate the polymer into oligomers. Analogous to 3, polymeric 4 involves the point-to-point association of (KN)2 rings, with the phenyl groups adopting a pseudo trans configuration with respect to the ring (Figure ). Within 4, there are two distinctly different four-membered rings that alternate throughout the polymeric chain. In one four-membered ring, the K(2) and K(2)′ cations are uncomplexed by any Lewis donor, forming close contacts with the aza-enolate moiety of the ligand only. In a second four-membered ring, a THF molecule coordinates to each K atom [K(1) and K(1)′] in an alternating fashion above and below the (KN)2 ring, minimizing steric repulsion. Each polymeric chain also forms close contacts with a second adjacent polymeric chain through vinylic K–C electrostatic interactions with a distance of 3.185(4) Å, completing the high coordination demands of potassium.

elements.content: All four crystalline complexes 1–4 were characterized by multinuclear NMR spectroscopy (1H, 13C, COSY, HSQC, and 7Li were applicable) in d 6-benzene solution. Complexes 1 and 2 indicate retention of the allylic bonding pattern, as observed in the crystal structures, rather than delocalization. However, the potassium complexes 3 and 4 show NMR spectra that are not consistent with their solid-state structures, with the anion possibly undergoing a further rearrangement.
elements.clean_text:
Solution Studies

All four crystalline complexes 1-4 were characterized by multinuclear NMR spectroscopy (1H, 13C, COSY, HSQC, and 7Li were applicable) in d 6-benzene solution. Complexes 1 and 2 indicate retention of the allylic bonding pattern, as observed in the crystal structures, rather than delocalization. However, the potassium complexes 3 and 4 show NMR spectra that are not consistent with their solid-state structures, with the anion possibly undergoing a further rearrangement.

elements.content: A section of the 1H NMR of dilithiated 1 is shown in Figure . At first appearance, there seems to be too many peaks, but by using 2D NMR (COSY and HSQC) techniques, they can all be successfully assigned. The α-methyl moiety (CH3) in 1 remains essentially unchanged at 1.19 ppm. In contrast, the benzyl proton (Ha) has been significantly shifted downfield to 4.13 ppm compared to it in the free amine (3.66 ppm). The central aza-allyl moiety in 1 can be characterized by the three signals at 5.80 ppm (Hb), 5.31 ppm (Hc), and 3.79 ppm (Hd) of which Hb and Hd are very broad doublets. The cis conformation of the double bond pattern seen in the solid-state structure is retained in the solution state with Hb and Hc having 2 J b–c of 7 Hz. The most upfield-shifted protons in 1 belong to the ortho-and para-protons of the phenyl group attached to the allyl moiety. Shifted by almost 2 ppm compared to the parent amine, their peaks come at 6.71 ppm (He), 6.45 ppm (He), and 6.20 ppm (Hg). This large upfield shift of the ortho- and para-protons can be attributed to the large deshielding effect of the nearby Li atom. The remainder of the ortho-phenyl protons (Hh) are slightly shifted downfield at 7.52 ppm with the meta-(Hi+f) and para-(Hj) peaks at 7.10 and 7.22 ppm, respectively, being largely unchanged compared to the parent amine. The TMEDA molecules appear as two very broad signals at 1.96 ppm for the CH3 and 1.74 ppm for the CH2 backbone. The extremely broad nature of these signals could suggest a fluxional system with the TMEDA coming on and off the Li cations when in solution. Similarly, the 7Li NMR spectra contains one broad signal at −0.54 ppm, which would be expected as both Li atoms are identical in their coordination environments.

elements.content: Solution NMR spectra of complex 2 was recorded in C6D6, confirming that the 1-aza-allyl configuration seen in the solid-state structure is retained in solution. In comparing the 1H NMR spectra of 2, shown in Figure , with that of the free parent allylamine, the most telling features are the disappearance of the benzylic protons CH2CHCHPh at 6.40 and 6.17 ppm and the emergence of two new broad signals at 7.00 ppm (Hb) and 4.32 ppm (Hc), corresponding to the protons of the newly moved double bond. Similarly, the CH2 protons in the parent amine ligand at 3.13 ppm have been replaced with a new broad CH2 signal (Hd) downfield-shifted to 3.59 ppm.

elements.content: Moving to the potassium aza-enolate compounds 3 and 4, 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy revealed that their solid-state structures are not retained in solution. This is evident by the distinct absence of two signals for the diastereotopic protons at ca. 3.5 ppm. The formation of a newly formed phenyl-propyl in 3 and the propyl group in 4 is characterized by the signals at 3.26, 2.78, and 2.09 ppm in 3 and 3.26, 1.83, and 1.05 ppm in complex 4. The delocalization of charge along the formed methylbenzylamine moiety is supported by the downfield shift of the ortho-H to 7.91 ppm in both complexes 3 and 4, while the benzylic proton [PhC( H )CH3], which resonates as a quartet at ca. 4 ppm, is absent. The emergence of a new singlet at 1.72 ppm in complex 3 and at 1.77 ppm in complex 4 can be assigned to a newly formed methyl group, confirmed by 13C J-modulation spectroscopy studies.

elements.content: The absence of the expected diastereotopic protons and delocalization of charge along the methylbenzylamine moiety in both the solution-state complexes of 3 and 4 suggest the formation of an imine (Figure ). Further analysis of the ortho-protons belonging to the methylbenzylamine group in 3 and 4 shows an integration value of one hydrogen, suggesting a proton shift and attachment of a potassium ion to one of the ortho-carbons on the phenyl ring to give rise to the new imine products [(C6H4K)C(CH3)NCH2CH2CH3] for 3 (Figure ) and [(C6H4K)C(CH3)NCH2CH2CH2Ph] for 4. Further evidence for the potassiated phenyl group in 3 is given by the 13C NMR and 13C J-modulation spectra, where four new quaternary centers at 163.4, 142.6, 141.4, and 128.1 ppm are observed. Hydrolysis of the 1H NMR solution sample of 3 furnished the sole imine organic product [PhC(CH3)NCH2CH2CH2Ph] with the ortho-protons belonging to the methylbenzylamine group now integrating to two hydrogen atoms.

elements.content: Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the Gaussian 09 suite of software to further investigate the structural analogues described in the lithiation reactions described above. Molecular geometry calculations commenced at the B3LYP/6-31G(d) level using crystal structure data as a starting point. Energies were subsequently improved using a larger basis set, 6-311+G(d,p).
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Calculations

Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the Gaussian 09 suite of software to further investigate the structural analogues described in the lithiation reactions described above. Molecular geometry calculations commenced at the B3LYP/6-31G(d) level using crystal structure data as a starting point. Energies were subsequently improved using a larger basis set, 6-311+G(d,p).

elements.content: As established in our earlier work the 1,3-sigmatropic rearrangement of the allylamide to the 1-aza-allyl structure is highly thermodynamically favored. In the present study, we were intrigued by the preference for Li2-mbpa 1 to undergo isomerization to the aza-allyl anion conformation, a change that is not evident in Li2-mba 6. Thus, we turned to computational methods to begin to understand the energetic difference between the two anionic forms and the impetus for each complex to adopt different structures. The calculated energies are presented in Table .

In the present study, we were intrigued by the preference for Li2-mbpa 1 to undergo isomerization to the aza-allyl anion conformation, a change that is not evident in Li2-mba 6. Thus, we turned to computational methods to begin to understand the energetic difference between the two anionic forms and the impetus for each complex to adopt different structures. The calculated energies are presented in Table .

Calculated Energies for the Range of Structures Incorporating the (<italic toggle="yes">S</italic>)-<italic toggle="yes">N</italic>-mba and (<italic toggle="yes">S</italic>)-<italic toggle="yes">N</italic>-mbpa Ligands with Li and TMEDA relative energy (kJ mol–1) isomer no. of ligands no. of Li atoms no. of TMEDA (S)-N-mba (S)-N-mbpa amide 1 2 1 0.​0 0.​0 aza-allyl –31.​3 –48.​7 amide 1 2 2 –77.​4 –77.​8 aza-allyl –115.​5 –153.​4 amide (dimer) 2 4 2 –75.​4 –58.​6 aza-allyl (dimer) –103.​8 –92.​6

Energies calculated at B3LYP/6-31G(d).

Includes the energy of unassocciated TMEDA ligands for equivalence.

Dimerization relative energies have been halved in order to compare to the equivalent monomer energies.

As can be seen in Figure , the energetic incentive for a 1,3-sigmatropic rearrangement is greater than that for dimerization of either Li2-mbpa or Li2-mba. However, the difference in relative energy in each case is substantially different. The energy of association granted by an additional TMEDA unit in the monomeric structure is clearly seen to favor the Li2-mbpa 1 structure over the corresponding dimer. However, in the dimeric Li2-mba structure 6, both ligands are able to approach all four lithium ions, with Li–ligand internuclear distances close to 2.0°Å, enhancing its thermodynamic stability. In contrast, the calculated structure for a Li2 -mbpa dimeric structure (not observed) demonstrates that the additional steric bulk from the phenyl group prohibits similarly close interaction with the Li ions. Attempts were made experimentally to isolate the dimeric dilithiated (S)-N-mbpa species by varying the solvent (Et2O, THF, hexane), donor ratios (Et2O, THF, TMEDA), and reaction temperatures without success.

elements.content: Our investigations into the metalation of the chiral secondary amine (S)-N-α-(methylbenzyl)phenylallylamine have shown that monometalation is achieved at the amido N atom when reacted with nBuNa or nBuK. Forming a dimeric aza-allyl complex with sodium in 2, the anion rearrangement is retained in both the solid and the solution state. In comparison, a polymeric aza-enolate complex 3 is observed with potassium in the solid state. Solution studies of 3 indicate a further rearrangement and hydrogen shift with one ortho-hydrogen atom, belonging to the phenyl group of the methylbenzylamine moiety, replaced with a potassium ion, forming the new imine complex [(C6H4K)C(CH3)NCH2CH2CH2Ph] in solution. The dimetalation of (S)-N-mbpa is achieved with nBuLi, regardless of the number of equivalents of metalating reagent used, suggesting it to be the most thermodynamically stable species in the reaction mixture. Metalation occurs at the amido N and vinylic C atoms, forming an aza-allyl dianion that retains its “allylic” bonding pattern in both its solid and its solution state. Finally, completing the series from previous research work on the amide ligand α-(methylbenzyl)allylamine, reaction of (R)-N-mba with nBuK resulted in the monopotassiated aza-enolate complex 4, which is polymeric in the solid state. Solution studies, similar to 3, indicate a rearrangement and hydrogen atom shift with the potassium ion located on an ortho-carbon belonging to the methylbenzylamine group forming the imine complex [(C6H4K)C(CH3)NCH2CH2CH3] in solution. DFT calculations into the dilithiated complex 1 show that the observed 1,3-sigmatropic rearrangement of the allylamide to the 1-aza-allyl structure is highly thermodynamically favored. The most energetically calculated stable species of 1 (by −153.4 kJ mol–1), the monomeric aza-allylic complex is observed experimentally, with the dimeric dilithiated 1 (by −68.4 kJ mol–1) not observed. This suggests that barriers to rearrangement/dimerization are most likely too high; however, it may still be possible for these to form, given the right crystallization conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Our investigations into the metalation of the chiral secondary amine (S)-N-α-(methylbenzyl)phenylallylamine have shown that monometalation is achieved at the amido N atom when reacted with nBuNa or nBuK. Forming a dimeric aza-allyl complex with sodium in 2, the anion rearrangement is retained in both the solid and the solution state. In comparison, a polymeric aza-enolate complex 3 is observed with potassium in the solid state. Solution studies of 3 indicate a further rearrangement and hydrogen shift with one ortho-hydrogen atom, belonging to the phenyl group of the methylbenzylamine moiety, replaced with a potassium ion, forming the new imine complex [(C6H4K)C(CH3)NCH2CH2CH2Ph] in solution. The dimetalation of (S)-N-mbpa is achieved with nBuLi, regardless of the number of equivalents of metalating reagent used, suggesting it to be the most thermodynamically stable species in the reaction mixture. Metalation occurs at the amido N and vinylic C atoms, forming an aza-allyl dianion that retains its "allylic" bonding pattern in both its solid and its solution state. Finally, completing the series from previous research work on the amide ligand α-(methylbenzyl)allylamine, reaction of (R)-N-mba with nBuK resulted in the monopotassiated aza-enolate complex 4, which is polymeric in the solid state. Solution studies, similar to 3, indicate a rearrangement and hydrogen atom shift with the potassium ion located on an ortho-carbon belonging to the methylbenzylamine group forming the imine complex [(C6H4K)C(CH3)NCH2CH2CH3] in solution. DFT calculations into the dilithiated complex 1 show that the observed 1,3-sigmatropic rearrangement of the allylamide to the 1-aza-allyl structure is highly thermodynamically favored. The most energetically calculated stable species of 1 (by -153.4 kJ mol-1), the monomeric aza-allylic complex is observed experimentally, with the dimeric dilithiated 1 (by -68.4 kJ mol-1) not observed. This suggests that barriers to rearrangement/dimerization are most likely too high; however, it may still be possible for these to form, given the right crystallization conditions.

elements.content: All reactions were performed under a nitrogen atmosphere and dry conditions. All synthesis and manipulations were undertaken with the use of a vacuum/nitrogen line and Schlenk techniques used. Water and oxygen were removed from hexane and THF using the MBRAUN SPS-800 solvent purification system and stored over 4 Å molecular sieves. TMEDA was dried by reflux over CaH2 and stored over 4 Å molecular sieves. nBuLi (1.6 M in hexanes) and tBuLi (1.7 M in hexanes) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and standardized before use. nBuNa, nBuK, S-N-mba, and S-N-mbpa were synthesized according to the literature procedures. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker DRX 400 MHz and Bruker DRX 300 MHz spectrometers with chemical shifts referenced internally to C6D6. Elemental analyses of 3 and 4 were performed by CMAS, Melbourne, Australia. Repeated attempts to obtain suitable elemental analysis of compounds 1 and 2 proved unsuccessful due to their extremely air-sensitive and reactive nature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All reactions were performed under a nitrogen atmosphere and dry conditions. All synthesis and manipulations were undertaken with the use of a vacuum/nitrogen line and Schlenk techniques used. Water and oxygen were removed from hexane and THF using the MBRAUN SPS-800 solvent purification system and stored over 4 Å molecular sieves. TMEDA was dried by reflux over CaH2 and stored over 4 Å molecular sieves. nBuLi (1.6 M in hexanes) and tBuLi (1.7 M in hexanes) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and standardized before use. nBuNa, nBuK, S-N-mba, and S-N-mbpa were synthesized according to the literature procedures. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker DRX 400 MHz and Bruker DRX 300 MHz spectrometers with chemical shifts referenced internally to C6D6. Elemental analyses of 3 and 4 were performed by CMAS, Melbourne, Australia. Repeated attempts to obtain suitable elemental analysis of compounds 1 and 2 proved unsuccessful due to their extremely air-sensitive and reactive nature.

elements.content: Crystallographic data of compound 1 were collected at the MX1 beamline at the Australian Synchrotron, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia, with silicon monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71070 Å). All data were collected at 100 K, maintained using an open flow of nitrogen. The software used for data collection and reduction of the data were BluIce and XDS. Crystallographic data for compound 2 were obtained on an OXFORD Gemini Ultra equipped with an OXFORD Cryosystems 700 Cryostream and cooled to 123(1) K. Data were collected with monochromatic (graphite) Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and processed using the CrysAlisProv 1.171.34.36 software; Lorentz, polarization, and absorption corrections (multiscan) were applied. Crystallographic data for compounds 3 and 4 were obtained on a Bruker X8 APEXII CCD diffractometer equipped with an OXFORD Cryosystems 700 Cryostream and cooled to 123(1) K. Data were collected with monochromatic (graphite) Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and processed using the Bruker Apex2 v2012.2.0 software; Lorentz, polarization, and absorption corrections (multiscan – SADABS) were applied. Compounds 1–4 were solved and refined with SHELX-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters unless otherwise indicated, and hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions using a riding model with C–H = 0.95–0.98 Å and U iso(H) = xU iso(C), x = 1.2 or 1.5.

Crystallographic Data

Crystallographic data of compound 1 were collected at the MX1 beamline at the Australian Synchrotron, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia, with silicon monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71070 Å). All data were collected at 100 K, maintained using an open flow of nitrogen. The software used for data collection and reduction of the data were BluIce and XDS. Crystallographic data for compound 2 were obtained on an OXFORD Gemini Ultra equipped with an OXFORD Cryosystems 700 Cryostream and cooled to 123(1) K. Data were collected with monochromatic (graphite) Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and processed using the CrysAlisProv 1.171.34.36 software; Lorentz, polarization, and absorption corrections (multiscan) were applied. Crystallographic data for compounds 3 and 4 were obtained on a Bruker X8 APEXII CCD diffractometer equipped with an OXFORD Cryosystems 700 Cryostream and cooled to 123(1) K. Data were collected with monochromatic (graphite) Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and processed using the Bruker Apex2 v2012.2.0 software; Lorentz, polarization, and absorption corrections (multiscan - SADABS) were applied. Compounds 1-4 were solved and refined with SHELX-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters unless otherwise indicated, and hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions using a riding model with C-H = 0.95-0.98 Å and U iso(H) = xU iso(C), x = 1.2 or 1.5.

(S)-N-mbpa (0.74 g, 3.1 mmol) was added to a stirring suspension of nBuK (0.30 g, 3.0 mmol) in hexane (8 mL) at 0 °C. The suspension was left to stir at room temperature for 1 h. cln_elements.content:
The three complexes of (S)-N-mbpa were prepared as shown in Scheme . Compound 1 was synthesized by addition of 1 equivalent of nBuLi to a hexane solution of (S)-N-mbpa at −50 °C. After warming to room temperature, the oily red solution was allowed to stir for 1 h before addition of TMEDA and sonication for 30 min. Storage of the dark red solution at room temperature for 24 h furnished a crop of red rhombic crystals of complex 1 in a 42% yield. Multiple attempts at the rational synthesis of 1, using 2 equiv of nBuLi and TMEDA or nBuLi/tBuLi mixtures with TMEDA, resulted in the formation of red oils and solids that produced no crystalline products. Analysis of the oils by NMR spectroscopy revealed a complicated mixture of species. Extending this chemistry to sodium, 2 was synthesized by the reaction of nBuNa with (S)-N-mbpa in hexane at 0 °C. Addition of TMEDA and reduction of the solvent volume in vacuo furnished a large crop of light yellow prism crystals of complex 2 in a 81% yield. Completing the series, the potassium analogue 3 was synthesized via the reaction of nBuK with (S)-N-mbpa in a hexane/THF solution at 0 °C. Storage of the solution at room temperature deposited a large crop of yellow needle crystals of complex 3 in a 76% yield.

Synthesis and Characterization of [{PhC(H)CH<sub>3</sub>NC(H)C(H)C(H)Ph}Li<sub>2</sub>(TMEDA)<sub>2</sub>] <bold>1</bold>

nBuLi (1.25 mL [1.6 M solution in hexane], 2.0 mmol) was added dropwise to a solution of (S)-N-mbpa (0.47 g, 2.0 mmol) in hexane (10 mL) at −50 °C. The cloudy white suspension was allowed to stir at −50 °C for 45 min. Next, TMEDA (0.30 mL, 2.0 mmol) was added, and the solution was allowed to warm to room temperature overnight. A claggy red solid was deposited, which, upon sonication for 30 min, gave a deep red solution. Storage of the red solution at room temperature overnight deposited a crop of red rhombic crystals: 0.40 g, 42% (max yield = 50%).

Synthesis and Characterization of [{PhC(H)CH<sub>3</sub>NCHCHCH<sub>2</sub>Ph}<sub>2</sub>Na<sub>2</sub>(TMEDA)<sub>2</sub>] <bold>2</bold>

nBuNa (0.16 g, 2.0 mmol) was suspended in hexane (10 mL), and (S)-N-mbpa (0.47 g, 2.0 mmol) was added dropwise at 0 °C to give a dark brown precipitate. After 1 h, TMEDA (0.30 mL, 2.0 mmol) was added, and the solution was stirred at room temperature overnight. The resulting light pink solution was reduced in volume in vacuo, and storage at room temperature overnight deposited a crop of light yellow prism crystals: 0.62 g, 81%.

Synthesis and Characterization of [PhC(CH<sub>2</sub>)N(CH<sub>2</sub>CH<sub>2</sub>CH<sub>2</sub>Ph)K]<sub>∞</sub> <bold>3</bold>

THF (2.0 mL) was added, resulting in the dissolution of the precipitate, forming a dark red solution, which was left to stir for 30 min at room temperature. Storage of this solution at room temperature overnight resulted in the deposition of a large crop of yellow needle crystals (0.65 g, 76%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, C6D6, 30 °C): δ 7.91 (1H, m, ortho-H), 7.21–7.14 (8H, m, Ar–H), 3.24 (2H, t, CH 2CH2CH2), 2.76 (2H, t, CH2 CH 2CH2), 2.07 (2H, m, CH2 CH2 CH 2), 1.72 (3H, s, CCH 3). 13C NMR (75 MHz, C6D6, 30 °C): δ 163.4 (ipso-PhCCH3), 142.6 (ipso-C), 141.1 (ipso-C), 128.1 (ipso-C), 129.4 (Ar-C), 128.9 (Ar-C), 128.9 (Ar-C), 128.6 (Ar-C), 127.8 (Ar-C), 126.9 (Ar-C), 125.9 (Ar-C), 51.2 (CH2CH2CH2), 34.1 (CH2CH2 CH2), 33.1 (CH2 CH2CH2), 14.6 (PhCCH3). Anal. Calcd. for C17H18KN: C, 74.1; H, 6.6; N, 5.1. Found: C, 74.5; H, 6.6; N, 5.3. mp 197–198 °C.

After warming to room temperature, the oily red solution was allowed to stir for 1 h before addition of TMEDA and sonication for 30 min. Storage of the dark red solution at room temperature for 24 h furnished a crop of red rhombic crystals of complex 1 in a 42% yield. Multiple attempts at the rational synthesis of 1, using 2 equiv of nBuLi and TMEDA or nBuLi/tBuLi mixtures with TMEDA, resulted in the formation of red oils and solids that produced no crystalline products. Analysis of the oils by NMR spectroscopy revealed a complicated mixture of species. Extending this chemistry to sodium, 2 was synthesized by the reaction of nBuNa with (S)-N-mbpa in hexane at 0 °C. Addition of TMEDA and reduction of the solvent volume in vacuo furnished a large crop of light yellow prism crystals of complex 2 in a 81% yield. Completing the series, the potassium analogue 3 was synthesized via the reaction of nBuK with (S)-N-mbpa in a hexane/THF solution at 0 °C. Storage of the solution at room temperature deposited a large crop of yellow needle crystals of complex 3 in a 76% yield.
